hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
gpt-4o-mini_translation: "'Ama'u sent forth the chief from Waikīkī, four warriors, and among them, there were thirty-eight men in total; thus, all were four. When they arrived at the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but there was no one there. And they were ready to return when Nāmakaokapāo'o called from the roof. They heard the voice, yet there was no sight of the body, so they asked: 'Where are you speaking from?' Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: 'Here I am up high.' Eight men climbed up, four on the back of the house and four in front of the house, where they found Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked: 'Why have you come to me?' They answered: 'We have come to battle with you, Nāmakaokapāo'o, a small boy like you, strong and extraordinarily brave, who has slain your father, Puali'i.'
gpt-4o-mini_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation> "'Ama'u sent forth the chief from Waikīkī, four warriors, and among them, there were thirty-eight men in total; thus, all were four. When they arrived at the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but there was no one there. And they were ready to return when Nāmakaokapāo'o called from the roof. They heard the voice, yet there was no sight of the body, so they asked: 'Where are you speaking from?' Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: 'Here I am up high.' Eight men climbed up, four on the back of the house and four in front of the house, where they found Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked: 'Why have you come to me?' They answered: 'We have come to battle with you, Nāmakaokapāo'o, a small boy like you, strong and extraordinarily brave, who has slain your father, Puali'i.'</translation>

<commentary> 
**Paragraph 12:**
• This passage continues to elaborate on the rising tensions and the imminent conflict in the narrative. Here, 'Ama'u (the chief) mobilizes four warriors from Waikīkī (a significant geographic region known for its cultural roots and connection to notable ali'i - chiefs) to confront Nāmakaokapāo'o (the protagonist previously introduced), which serves to elevate the stakes of the unfolding story. 
   
– The name 'Ama'u (the one who treats) can evoke images of royalty or leadership, suggesting the character plays a pivotal role in guiding his warriors. Waikīkī, associated with both beauty and historic battles, invokes the richness of Hawaiian history, often signaling that this setting is not just a backdrop but an active participant in the tale.

• The warriors, numbering thirty-eight, reinforces the significance of the numbers in Hawaiian tradition, where they often symbolize strength and unity, but also can carry deeper meanings. The specific count may indicate the potential for a formidable group, enhancing the narrative tension and creating an immediate sense of danger for Nāmakaokapāo'o.

• The description of Nāmakaokapāo'o as "a small boy" in contrast to the warriors reflects a common motif in Hawaiian narratives where a seemingly weaker or smaller protagonist exhibits extraordinary strength and bravery — a clear indicator of his heroic status destined to overcome greater odds. This trope elevates the narrative to a level of mythological allegory, suggestive of the triumph of the underdog, an important theme in both modern and ancient tales.

• The scene where Nāmakaokapāo'o calls down from the roof adds a layer of supernatural or divine quality to his character, allowing for him to appear in a space that grants him greater perspective and control over events below. This imagery connects to the concept of "mana" (spiritual power) in Hawaiian cosmology, representing the elevated status and strength of Nāmakaokapāo'o.

• As for the mention of his father, Puali'i, further context arises: he is not only common in name but in significance — foreshadowing the need for resolution regarding paternal legacy and conflict. Puali'i's earlier demise serves as a powerful motivator for Nāmakaokapāo'o as he navigates his challenges, symbolizing how familial bonds drive the narratives in Hawaiian culture.

• This passage reflects the themes of honor in battle, the call to arms, and the bravery of youth, resonating deeply with the cultural practices regarding conflict resolution and warrior ethics within ancient Hawaiian society and echoing the values of the 'Ai Kapu era — where rituals surrounding conflict played crucial roles in maintaining societal order.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
